clinical_study.brief_title: Mindfulness for People With Incurable Cancer
clinical_study.official_title: A Pilot Investigation of a Mindfulness Course for People With Incurable Cancer

collaborator.agency: University Hospitals of Morecambe Bay NHS Foundation Trust

brief_summary.textblock: The study will investigate whether a mindfulness course can help people with incurable cancer who are seen by oncologists in a particular National Health Service Hospital Trust in the United Kingdom.

detailed_description.textblock:
It can be hard to come to terms with living with a life limiting condition such as incurable cancer and individuals are at risk of experiencing high levels of psychological distress, which can often be overlooked when the focus is on managing physical symptoms.
Mindfulness-based interventions have been shown to be helpful in reducing distress for people with cancer generally. This pilot study will use an established mindfulness programme called mindfulness for health with people with cancer which is incurable to see if this type of intervention is acceptable and useful for this group of people.

primary_outcome.measure: Acceptability and usefulness of intervention for participants
primary_outcome.time_frame: Within 4 weeks of the end of the intervention
primary_outcome.description: This will be a qualitative outcome, collected via semi-structured interview

secondary_outcome.measure: Acceptability and usefulness of intervention for participants- 3 months
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 3 months following completion of the intervention
secondary_outcome.description: This will be a qualitative outcome, collected via semi-structured interview

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in depression anxiety and stress
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Collected before the intervention (up to 4 weeks before the intervention) and within 4 weeks of the end of the intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Using the Depression, Anxiety and Stress (DASS21) scale we will measure the change post intervention score - pre intervention score. Each subscale (depression, anxiety and stress) ranges from 0-21, with higher scores indicating higher distress. A greater decrease in scores, would mean a greater improvement in symptoms.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Deemed by the oncologist to have incurable cancer
- Patient of the University Hospitals of Morecambe Bay NHS Foundation Trust
- Treated by an oncologist
- Believe they are able to commit to attending most of the mindfulness course sessions
- Oncologist assesses they are well enough to participate in the intervention
Exclusion Criteria:
- Having any other condition or difficulty which the medical team thinks would compromise their participation in the study.
